html.title: CoinSampo
html.description: The Sampo-UI framework makes it possible to create highly customizable, user-friendly, and responsive user interfaces using current state-of-the-art JavaScript libraries and data from SPARQL endpoints.

appDescription1: Sampo is a web service for searching and studying place names. The search results can be viewed as a table, on maps, and as statistical distributions. Historical and current background maps are provided.
appDescription2: Start by choosing source dataset(s) and input a place name on the search field. Alternatively you can search by area.
selectPerspective: CoinSampo is a prototype cultural heritage service that open data about the numismatic citizen finds reported in Finland in 2013-2023.
mainPageImageLicence: CoinSampo is a research prototype developed in Semantic Computing research group of Aalto University and University of Helsinki, based on the coin finds data of the Finnish National Museum.
backendErrorText: One of the backend services is not available at the moment. Please try again later.

facetBar.sortByNumberOfSearchResults: Sort by number of search results

csvDownload.finds: Download CSV (UTF-8 encoding, delimiter ','). Licence: CC BY 4.0. Kansallismuseo, Museovirasto, Semantic Computing Research Group.

exportToYasgui: open the result table query in yasgui sparql editor
resultsAsCSV: download the search results as a CSV table

instancePageGeneral.introduction: This landing page provides a human-readable summary of the data points that link to this {entity}.

finds.label: Coin Finds
finds.shortDescription: Coin finds reported in Finland in 2013-2023
finds.longDescription:
This perspective can be used to search Finnish coin finds using the faceted filters on the left-hand side of the page. The database contains more than 18.000 coin finds reported to the National Heritage between 2013 and 2013. The search results can be browsed and visualised using the following tabs:

  • TABLE tab presents the coin finds as a list with attributes. By selecting a link for a concept, you can also access its entity pages.
  • MAP tab presents the locations where the coins were found. Several base maps are available, including historical maps. Archaeological sites from the Ancient Relics Register can be added as a layer (zoom level 13), and a 200 m protection zone within which archaeology should not be searched can be calculated. You can break down clusters, eventually showing individual sites, by zooming in on the map or by clicking on a cluster. Please note that the accuracy of the find location varies; the coordinate points are as given in the original report and may indicate the exact location of the find or, for example, the centre of the field where the find was made. About 8% of the finds lack coordinates and are not displayed on the map.
  • HEAT MAP tab generates a kernel density estimation surface that illustrates broader patterns in the distribution of finds. Zooming in or out changes the kernel width used, creating a more detailed or a more general view of the distribution.
  • PIE/BAR CHART presents the contents of the statistically as a pie or a bar chart. The following, and more, attribute categories can be selected: period, authority, mint and context.
  • AORISTIC CHART tab illustrates temporal distribution in the data. As many of the coins can only be dated by approximate broad period a conventional statistical timeline visualization cannot be used. The aorist chart is based on a probabilistic calculation of the average weight of coin finds falling into the boxes (columns) in which the timeline is divided (you can choose between four box sizes).
  • MINTS tab visualizes the numbers of selected coins according to their mint locations with a kernel density estimation map surface.
  • MIGRATIONS tab presents the movement of the coins from their minting locations (blue end) to their discovery sites (red end). If the place where the coin was struck is not known, no arc is drawn. For visual clarity, the arc terminated at the centre of find municipality rather than at the exact location of the find. Zooming in closer and selecting an arc will open a window listing the coins that make up that arc; selecting an individual coin will take you to its entity page. You can tilt the map view on a Windows machine by clicking the right mouse button and moving the arrow, or on a Mac by pressing mouse/control pad + control and moving the arrow.
  • FIND YEAR ANIMATIO tab shows where in Finland coin finds were reported each year from 2013 to 2023.
  • MINTING YEAR ANIMATION tab shows the arrival of coins in Finland from the Late Iron Age onwards, according to their earliest estimated year of minting (terminus post quem).
  • CSV tab allows you to download the coin finds you have selected using the faceted search, or all coin finds, as a CSV file.

textSearch.label: Text search
textSearch.description: Search with free text from fields such as label, note, or ascension number. Use quotation marks to search for terms that contain a space, such as "Charles IX". Some terms may be replaced with the wildcard operator, such as "Christ*" (Christina, Christian II).

prefLabel.label: Label
prefLabel.description: A short label describing the object.

localId.label: ID
localId.description: The ID-value of the coin finds in CoinSampo. Composed of the year of reporting combined with the database record number.

image.label: Finna search
image.description: An image illustrating the broad coin type. Automatically pulled from Finna

imageDescription.label: Image description
imageDescription.description: The local ID-value of the coin finds in CoinSampo. Composed of the year of reporting combined with the database record number.

context.label: Context
context.description: Modern, historical or natural environment context in which the coin was reported as discovered.

municipality.label: Municipality
municipality.description: The municipality from which the coin was discovered. Not all finds have were reported with more precise findspot information (coordinate location), in which case they are not shown on the map tab.

denomination.label: Denomination
denomination.description: Coin denominations, such as marks, dirhems and kopeks, and their nominal values. This also includes other coin types, such as game money, copies and forgeries, and planchets.

mint.label: Mint
mint.description: City or mint in which the coin was struck. This level of precision is not known for all coins, in which case see Country or region.

country.label: Country/Region
country.description: Country or region (including broader political concepts such as regions controlled by dynasties) in which the coin was struck.

authority.label: Authority
authority.description: The name of the authority that minted the coin, such as Queen Christina. It two or more authorities or regnal numbers are separated with a slash (e.g., Otto II/III) it is not possible to date the specific coin more precisely. If these are separeted with &, the coin was released jointly by two authorities such as a secular ruler and a bishop.

qualifier.label: Numismatic type
qualifier.description: Qualifier based on the numismatic type of the coin, such as klippe, wire money, notgeld or standardized qualifiers for Viking Age coins (Long Cross, Otto Adelheid, Sachsenpfennig).

earliestYear.label: t.p.q.
earliestYear.description: Terminus post quem, or earliest possible year of minting.

latestYear.label: t.a.q.
latestYear.description: Terminus ante quem, or earliest possible year of minting.

earliestYearFacet.label: Earliest year (t.p.q.)
earliestYearFacet.description: Set the range of dates within which the earliest possible year (terminus post quem) of minting can fall.

latestYearFacet.label: Latest year (t.a.q.)
latestYearFacet.description: Set the range of dates within which the latest possible year (terminus ante quem) of minting can fall.

note.label: Note
note.description: Further information about the coin find as a free text field. In Finnish only

ascensionNumber.label: Ascension no.
ascensionNumber.description: The Finnish Heritage Agency (KM) or Numismatic collections (RK) ascension number if the coin has been claimed into the national collections. More recent (c. 2021 onwards) finds that have been claimed do not yet have a KM number.

registrationYear.label: Registration year
registrationYear.description: The year the coin was reported to the Finnish Heritage Agency.

mints.label: Mints
mints.shortDescription: Coin mints present in this data
mints.longDescription:
The mints perspectives offers information on the mints based on the towns or places in which they were located.

  • TABLE tab presents mints as a list with attributes. By selecting a link for a concept, you can also access its entity pages.
  • MAP tab shows the geographical locations of mints. Wikidata has been used for coordinate information.

prefLabel.label: Label
prefLabel.description: A short label describing the object.

authority.label: Authority
authority.description: Authorities associated with the mint in the data.

period.label: Period
period.description: Periods associated with the mint in the data.

find.label: Finds
find.description: Coin finds minted in this place.

municipality.label: Municipality found in
municipality.description: Municipalities where coins from the mint have been found in the data.

denomination.label: Denomination
denomination.description: Denominations from this mint in the data.

country.label: Country
country.description: Country associated this mint in the data.

material.label: Material
material.description: The materials of the coins from this mint in the data

qualifier.label: Qualifier
qualifier.description: Numismatic types associated with this mint in the data

authorities.label: Authorities
authorities.longDescription: The Authorities perspective presents the individuals in whose name coins have been issued as a table. Selecting a link will also take you to the entity pages.

textSearch.label: Text search
textSearch.description: Search with free text from fields such as label, note, or ascension number. Use quotation marks to search for terms that contain a space, such as "Charles IX". Some terms may be replaced with the wildcard operator, such as "Christ*" (Christina, Christian II).

qualifier.label: Numismatic type
qualifier.description: Qualifier based on the numismatic type of the coin, such as klippe, wire money, notgeld or standardized qualifiers for Viking Age coins (Long Cross, Otto Adelheid, Sachsenpfennig).

find.label: Finds
find.description: Coin finds associated with this authority.

country.label: Country/Area
country.description: Country or area associated with the authority in the data.

prefLabel.label: Label
prefLabel.description: A short label describing this authority.

period.label: Period
period.description: Periods associated with the authority in the data.

municipality.label: Municipality found in
municipality.description: Municipalities where coins from this authority have been found in the data.

denomination.label: Denomination
denomination.description: Denominations issued by the authority in the data, such as marks, disherms or kopeks. This also includes other coin types, such as game money, copies and forgeries, and planchets.

material.label: Material
material.description: The materials of the coins from this authority in the data

image.label: Image
image.description: Image representing the authority. Source: wikidata.

types.label: Coin Types
types.shortDescription: Broad coin categories based on denomination and authority
types.longDescription:
Use this perspective to access data related to physical manuscript objects. If two or more source datasets include the same manuscript and this has been verified, the information from the source datasets has been merged into one manuscript. See instructions for using the filters. The result view can be selected using the tabs:

  • TABLE view includes all manuscripts in the MMM data. One table row is equivalent to one manuscript.
  • PRODUCTION PLACES view visualizes the connection between manuscripts and the places where they were produced.
  • MIGRATIONS view visualizes the migration of a manuscript from place of production to its most recently observed location.
  • EXPORT the SPARQL query used to generate the result table view into YASGUI query editor.

instancePage.label: Coin
instancePage.description:
MMM’s Manuscript entity corresponds to FRBRoo’s Manifestation Singleton, defined as "physical objects that each carry an instance of [an Expression], and that were produced as unique objects..." The various types of records that describe manuscripts in each of the three contributing MMM datasets have been mapped to this entity.

Manuscript labels

If the Bibale or Oxford databases reference a shelf mark for the manuscript, that information will appear as its label. Otherwise, an SDBM ID number will serve as its label. SDBM ID numbers contain prefixes that indicate different things about the type of record they contain:

  • SDBM_MS: SDBM Manuscript Record, which aggregates the data of two or more SDBM Entries. Each Entry represents a different observation of a manuscript at a different point in time, derived from various sources.
  • SDBM_MS_orphan: a single Entry in the SDBM, meaning it has not been linked to any other Entries and therefore has no SDBM Manuscript Record.
  • SDBM_MS_part: a record identified as a fragment of a larger manuscript.

prefLabel.label: Label
prefLabel.description: A short label describing the object.

image.label: Type image
image.description: An image illustrating the broad coin type. Automatically pulled from Finna

context.label: Context
context.description: The intellectual content (works) contained in the manuscript.

period.label: Period
period.description: The linguistic versions of the works contained in the manuscript.

municipality.label: Municipality
municipality.description: The linguistic versions of the works contained in the manuscript.

denomination.label: Denomination
denomination.description: The linguistic versions of the works contained in the manuscript.

mint.label: Mint
mint.description: The source dataset(s) (Bibale, Bodleian, or SDBM) contributing the information on the manuscript. If two or more source datasets include the same manuscript and this has been manually verified, the information from the source datasets have been merged into one manuscript (table row). Click on the links to view the original record on the source’s website.

material.label: Material
material.description: The main material of the coin.

aboutThePortalPartOne:
Tietoa kuvista

Etusivun kuvat:

Dirhameita, Frida Ehrnsten, Kansallismuseo;

Kuusinainen, Kansallismuseo, Numismaattiset kokoelmat CC BY 4.0

Kuningatar Kristiina, Nationalmuseet, S. Bourdon

Sammon taonta, Kansallisgalleria, A. Gallen-Kallela

Muuta:

Entiteettien sivuille ladataan automaattisesti kuvia Finnasta sekä Wikidata ja Wikimedia Commons palveluista. Nämä kuvat voivat olla väliaikaisesta toimimatta, jos lähdepalvelussa on ongelmia.
instructions:
Instructions

The search functionality of this semantic portal is based on the faceted search paradigm. By default each perspective displays all results from the corresponding class. This default result set can be narrowed down by using the filters on the left.

Using a single filter

Selecting values within a filter

All possible values for a filter are displayed either as a list or as a hierarchical tree structure (if available). The number of results is shown in brackets for each value. Once a value is selected, the results are automatically updated. To prevent further selections that do not return any results, also the possible values for all other filters are updated at the same time.

Multiple values can be selected within a single filter. Selecting multiple values generates results that contain any of the selected values. For example, selecting both Saint Augustine and Saint Jerome as an Author returns results that include either Saint Augustine OR Saint Jerome as an Author.

Selected values of a filter appear in the Active filters section at the top of the list of filters. To deselect a filter, click the X mark next to it within the Active filters section. You can also deselect a filter value by unchecking the checkmark in the filter’s value list. The Active filters section only appears if there are filter values currently selected.

Searching within a filter

Search within a filter by using the search field at the top of each filter. All possible values of a filter remain visible at all times. The values of the filter that match the search term are indicated by a purple underline.

Steps for searching within filters:

  1. Type search term into search field. If there are matches, a number will appear to the right of the search field, indicating the number of filter values that match the search term.
  2. Click the arrows to the right of the search field to cycle through the results. As you click the arrow, a different filter value will appear at the top of the list. Matched filters are underlined in purple.
  3. Click the checkmark next to a filter value to activate it. The results (and also other filters) are automatically updated.

Using multiple filters simultaneously

The effectiveness of faceted search is realized when multiple filters are applied at the same time. As in many e-commerce sites, a logical AND is always used between the filters. For example selecting Saint Augustine and Saint Jerome as an Author and Sir Thomas Phillipps and Thomas Thorpe as an Owner, the results are narrowed down as follows:

(Author: Saint Augustine OR Author: Saint Jerome)

AND

(Owner: Sir Thomas Phillipps OR Owner: Thomas Thorpe)

We are interested in your feedback on the functionality, coverage, and usefulness of the portal and its data.

Please complete our Feedback Survey Form (add link).

You can also contact us via email: ... or DM us on Twitter: ...

Please be aware that this portal’s response times may be affected by the size and complexity of the underlying knowledge graph.
